header_1: H5N1 in Wild birds in Biologists tagging, checking birds to track avian flu in state
content_1: USA. Avian influenza surveillance continues. Reports on the current surveillance in Connecticut:
header_2: H5N1 in Wild birds in Though No Impending Threat, Avian Flu Still On State's Radar
content_2:
Germany. Reuters
			reported on October 25 that bird flu may become endemic in parts of Europe.
			"It seems that a new chapter in the evolution of avian influenza may
			be unfolding silently in the heart of Europe," Joseph Domenech, chief
			veterinary officer of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), said
			in a statement. The statement came after German scientists detected H5N1
			in dead domestic ducks which had appeared to be healthy.
			Domenech said that H5N1 may become endemic in parts of Europe, such as
			the Black Sea area, because domestic ducks and geese are more of a vector
			in the spread of bird flu than previously thought.
header_3:
Vietnam. in Bird flu has been
			detected in Vietnam for a second time this month. Recently, 310 two-month
			old ducklings have died (290 of them died on October 23) at a farm in the
			central province of Quang Tri. H5N1 has been found in the dead ducks, according
			to the Hoang Van Nam, the head of the Agriculture Ministry’s Animal Health
			Department. (more...)
